Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Chili shrimp" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(July 2024)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Chili shrimp** ([simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 干烧明虾; [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 乾燒明蝦; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *gān shāo míngxiā* or [simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 明虾; [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 明蝦; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *míngxiā*) is a dish of stir-fried [shrimp](/wiki/Shrimp_and_prawn_as_food) in [chili sauce](/wiki/Chili_sauce) (which may use [doubanjiang](/wiki/Doubanjiang)) in [Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine). It is a part of both [Sichuan](/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine) and [Shanghai cuisines](/wiki/Shanghai_cuisine). The Sichuan version has a crisp texture and uses dried chillis, onions, and tomatoes. In [Japanese Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Japanese_Chinese_cuisine), ***ebi-chiri*** ([Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_language): エビチリ) is derived from Shanghai-style [Sichuan cuisine](/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine). It consists of stir-fried [shrimp](/wiki/Shrimp_and_prawn_as_food) in [chilli sauce](/wiki/Hot_sauce). It has a history in Japan. According to *[Iron Chef](/wiki/Iron_Chef)*, *ebi-chiri* was introduced to and popularized in Japan by [Chen Kenmin](/wiki/Chen_Kenmin), father of Iron Chef Chinese [Chen Kenichi](/wiki/Chen_Kenichi).[*citation needed*] In [Korean Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Korean_Chinese_cuisine), chili shrimp is called ***kkansyo-saeu*** ([Korean](/wiki/Korean_language): 깐쇼새우), a named consisting of the word *kkansyo* derived from Chinese *gān shāo* (乾燒, "dry braising") and *saeu* meaning "shrimp" in Korean, or ***chilli-saeu*** ([Korean](/wiki/Korean_language): 칠리새우) with the English-derived word *chilli*.[*citation needed*] There is a Singaporean version of chili shrimp derived from the Sichuan version, but it has a moist texture and uses fresh chili peppers. *[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times)* stated that the Singapore version "resembles only slightly the Chinese version." - [Chili chicken](/wiki/Chili_chicken) - [List of seafood dishes](/wiki/List_of_seafood_dishes) - Food portal - Wells, Patricia.
